text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with grilled flank steak pastrami
that's right one of these years I will
do a proper post rami recipe which does
take a few days and a fair amount of
effort but in the meantime I'd like to
present this alternative which only
takes a couple hours and virtually no
effort so this should go over very well
with the Millennials in the audience
apparently my consultants tell me you
guys want everything fast and easy hey I
don't blame you and while I'm not gonna
lie and say this was exactly like a
traditional pastrami I can tell you it
was exactly like something very
delicious to eat so let's go ahead and
get started and first up we have to do
the pastrami spice rub and for that
we're going to need some freshly ground
black pepper
and please note we're doing a little
larger grind than we usually do we
definitely want to see some of those
larger pieces of crack pepper on the
surface and then to that we will add the
second most important pastrami spice
coriander which believe it or not is
made from the ground seeds of what we
call cilantro just a little bonus spice
trivia and then of course we're also
going to need some kosher salt and a
good amount of it as well as some
paprika and some dry mustard and we'll
go ahead and give that a mix with our
freakishly small freakishly small wooden
spoon and as soon as that is combined we
can set it aside and move on to the
flank steak and there it is I have one
trimmed a beef flank steak and generally
when you buy these most of the tougher
connective tissue has been trimmed off
but you might see a little bit of this
stuff on the side which you can trim off
I don't by the time this is grilled
you'll never know that's they're the
really tough and edible stuff is up here
and that's been removed and then before
we apply our spices we got to do a
couple things first of all I want to
drizzle on a little bit of vegetable oil
and I want to rub that on both sides of
the meat and that's going to sort of
help our spices adhere to the surface
plus as you may know fat is a great
transfer of flavor so I'm going to rub
down both sides and then once that's
been completed we're going to grab a
fork and get stab you with this I'm
gonna go ahead and get both sides the
old poka poka all over and that's going
to help those flavors penetrate a little
more deeply into the Meads and by the
way they do make a special tool to do
this with that you definitely shouldn't
buy especially if you have access to
Forks and once our flank has been
thoroughly poked we can go ahead and
apply the spices so I'm going to use
half on each side we will sprinkle it
over and give it a good rub
and if it looks like I'm putting a lot
on here I am in fact it may have been a
little too much but as usual I will put
the appropriate amounts on the blog post
but anyway we're going to apply a very
generous coat of the rub to both sides
at which point the prep on this is done
and then what I'm going to suggest is we
wrap this right back up in the same
butcher paper and pop that in the fridge
for anywhere between two hours and
overnight ensure if you're just
absolutely horrible at time management
and you have to cook this right now it's
probably going to be fine I mean just a
plain grilled flank steak is delicious
so if you have the wicked munchies and
have to cook it right away go ahead but
I did pop mine into the fridge for a
couple hours to let those flavors
penetrate thoroughly at which point we
can pull it out and start thinking about
grilling this and for most things that I
marinade for the grill I generally don't
let them warm up to room temp but in
this case I do recommend leaving this
out for about thirty minutes to come up
a little closer to room temp and I will
explain why in a post but I do think for
this particular recipe that works a
little better so I did let mine sit out
for about 20-30 minutes after which I
headed to the grill to cook this up and
as usual I'm using some nice charcoal
remember pastrami is smoked so while you
can cook this any way you want I really
think this is the way you want to go and
right here just by reflex I give it the
old half turn so I could get those
beautiful grill marks which for
something like this is kind of pointless
because we do have such a thick layer a
spice rub on there you're really not
going to get much in the way of grill
marks as you can see in fact I'm like
most grilled things this doesn't look
particularly good until it's done but
anyway we're going to grill that up to
our desired degree of doneness which for
me for this dish is medium as you know I
generally lean more towards medium rare
for grilled steaks but because we're
attempting some kind of faux pastrami
here we want something that's going to
have a little firmer of a texture and of
course I always recommend testing with a
thermometer
so at least if something goes wrong you
can blame the thermometer and I was
shooting for something around 135 ish
okay I still want it pink but like I
said I do want it a little firmer than
what you get with a rare or medium rare
and then once our meat is done to our
liking we'll pull that off and we will
let that rest and rest really well or if
you want to eat this nice and hot go
ahead let it rest five minutes and start
slicing but not me I let mine cool down
at least 15 minutes I want to make sure
all those juices had time to
redistribute
and for optimum texture and maximum
flavor I think just warm is perfect and
once our meat has rested properly we'll
go ahead and slice it thinly against the
grain as you know only a psychopath
slices with the grain and his food
wishes tradition dictates I will stop
after a few slices and give it a little
taste which was amazing smoky delicious
and as far as the flavor goes fairly
pastrami like and yes absolutely you
could just slice this and serve a dinner
plate style but I was more in the mood
for a pastrami sandwich so I piled some
up on some marble rye and by the way
recent studies have shown that four out
of five indecisive rye bread shoppers
choose marble but anyway I'm going to
serve that up on some rye that's been
generously slathered with mustard and
not just any mustard I snuck a little
bit of honey in there and I'll tell you
why in a second so we'll go ahead we'll
cut that in half and plate it up in our
grilled flank steak pastrami in Sandwich
form is done and since I'd already
tasted it I knew it was going to be good
but not surprisingly it was even better
on the bread with the mustard and the
reason we want to sneak a little bit of
honey into that mustard is because a
traditional corned beef is cured with
salt and sugar so there is a little bit
of sweetness in the background which is
not present in this recipe so to offset
that we'll just do a little sweetness
with the mustard and by the way I can't
help notice you staring at my pickle
that is one of Chef John's famous
naturally fermented dill pickles the yes
I will be showing you sometime soon so
stay tuned for that but right now it's
all about this beautiful pastrami like
beef and how really simple delicious and
relatively fast that was so I really do
hope you give this a try head over to
food wishes comm for all the ingredient
amounts and more folks usual and as
always enjoy
you
